DOLLI 2 Project Presentation Video Presentation Bernd Bruegge Harald Stangl Maximilian Reiss Technische 
Universitaet Muenchen Technische Universitaet Muenchen Technische Universitaet Muenchen Chair for Applied 
Software Engineering Chair for Applied Software Engineering Chair for Applied Software Engineering bruegge@in.tum.de 
stanglh@in.tum.de reissm@in.tum.de Abstract The DOLLI 2 project was the successor to a large-scale educational 
student project course with a real customer, offered to students in their second year. Once again, in 
the time frame of a single semester a functional system was developed and delivered to the customer. 
We repeated the shift from a traditional lifecycle to an agile process during the project, and used video 
techniques for defining re­quirements and meeting capture. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.3.2 [Computers 
and Education]: Computer and Information Science Edu­cation - Computer science education. K.6.1 [Management 
of Computing and Information Systems]: Project and People Management - Systems analysis and design, Sys­tems 
development, Management techniques. General Terms Management, Experimentation, Human Factors Keywords 
Video-based requirements engineering, scenario­based design, teaching software engineering, single project 
course 1. Voice-over text In the winter term 2008, the DOLLI 2 project, a sequel to the highly successful 
DOLLI project, took place. And just like its predecessor, it differed substantially from other student 
projects that are normally held at universities in the subject of computer science. The majority of the 
participants were students in their third semester. Although there were nearly thirty of them, they had 
to jointly work together to solve the problem they were posed. The teams that were formed were responsible 
each for one of the subsystems that were identified during the initial subsystem decomposition. Copyright 
is held by the autor/owner(s). OOPSLA 2009, October 25-29, 2009, Orlando, FL, USA. ACM 978-1-60558-768-4/09/10. 
 In contrast to typical student projects, the chair did not take the role of the customer, but with the 
Munich airport a real industry client could be found. Representatives of the airport were involved during 
the whole project duration, and their feedback was taken on multiple occasions to har­monize the development 
and their expectations. To keep the administrative workload for the instructor as low as possible, the 
teams were taught to work in a self­organizing way. By employing Apple's Podcast Producer technology, 
they could record their meetings for further reference. The videos were automatically captured, con­verted 
and posted on the team's blog. One result of the preceding project was a three­dimensional representation 
of the airport that allows to navigate through the airport and watch trackable objects like cars and 
airplanes as they move around. The challenge of this year's project was to create an in­tegration of 
the facility management systems to enable em­ployees to view and change the status of devices like elevators, 
lights and ventilation from within the three­dimensional view. Additionally, an iPhone client had to 
be developed to al­low the very same access from a mobile device while the user is on the road. The project 
not only served as a teaching measure, but also to investigate topics in the field of software engineer­ing 
from a research perspective. One of the tools currently under development at the chair is called "unicase". 
It aims at connecting all relevant artifacts that are important during software development. This total 
integration allows to easily link related items like use cases and models of implementing classes as 
well as project management artifacts like tasks and Sprint plan­nings. This enables traceability not 
only from requirements to code, but also takes the managerial aspects into account.  During the DOLLI 
2 project, it was investigated how changes on artifacts could be communicated best to af­fected project 
members. We also investigated the use of video technology to im­prove the requirements negotiation process. 
The idea is to create visual representations of the scenarios to give the customer a good idea about 
how the future system will work from the user's perspective. As the system does not exist at that point 
of time, we used GUI mock ups and green screen technology to make the video look as con­vincing as possible. 
In the first project we already successfully combined both the Unified Process and Scrum, which is an 
agile process. To see if this switch is repeatable, we once again started with a more traditional process 
for Requirements Engineering, System Design and Object Design. After the design was stable, most of the 
implementation was done during a two week Scrum phase, which took place at the airport itself. Just like 
last year, the switch worked without any major problems. At the end of the project the students presented 
their re­sults in the target environment of terminal 1 at the Munich airport. More than 50 people attended 
this event and were impressed by the actually working interaction between the DOLLI system and the existing 
facility management sys­tems. Although the required effort from the students was un­doubtedly higher 
than for typical student projects, the gain in real life project experience is a valuable preparation 
for the time after graduation.
